Award.AwardTitle: ICAM - Institute for Complex Adaptive Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract

Many of the materials of great interest and importance for society - including magnets, novel materials for solar energy conversion, biological or biologically inspired materials, and superconductors - exhibit "emergence": their unique and important properties emerge from their subunits such as atoms or proteins in an unforeseen manner from experimental observation. A sensible goal is to elucidate mathematically precise descriptions of the organizing principles describing these phenomena to guide future discovery. This understanding requires an integration of approaches from many disciplines such as physics, biology, chemistry, and engineering, and no one institution - or nation - has the expertise to fully understand these organizing principles by themselves. The Institute for Complex Adaptive Matter brings together distinguished senior scientists from across the US and abroad to cutting edge workshops on emergent phenomena in quantum matter (such as cold atomic condensates and superconductors), soft matter (such as self-replicating materials and active fluids), and biological matter (such as self-assembling biomolecule matrices and quantitative neuroscience) with a goal toward making substantive progress on advancing our understanding of these important problems. These workshops fully integrate young graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to assure that the next generation of emergent materials scientists will be immersed in the process.

Technical Abstract

All the ICAM workshops are discussion oriented (at least half the time is set aside for discussion), must include an explicit plan for active participation and engagement of junior scientists, for interaction between senior scientists from diverse disciplines, for video archiving of lectures, and for production of an overview paper from the workshop. When appropriate, workshop organizers must develop a plan to develop inputs to the materials genome initiative for placement of relevant data and software. Workshops are decided in consultation with the ICAM Science Steering committee from among: (i) spin-orbit supermaterials in solids and cold atom condensates, (ii) digital design of quantum materials, (iii) self-replicating materials, (iv) active materials (such as fluids with engineered swimming particles), (v) self-assembly of biological materials for materials applications, (vi) materials science interplay with the quantitative understanding of the brain, or (vii) important new topics proposed by the emergent matter community.

This award is supported jointly by the Condensed Matter Physcis and Biomaterials Programs in the Division of Materials Research, the Physics of Living Systems and Computational Physics Programs in the Division of Physics, and the Molecular Biophysics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for DMR-1411344, “ICAM-Institute for Complex Adaptive Matter”

 

This project enabled the support of 31 highly interactive scientific workshops at the leading edge of our understanding of emergent phenomena in matters, in which the “sum” of the behaviors is greater than a mere composition of the well understood interacting “smaller parts.”  The figures attached to this report provide some sense of the exciting science including: 1) snapshots from a poster session at the Biologically Enabled Self Assembly workshop at Florida A&M in 2015; 2) Images from a public lecture in 2016 at the workshop on “Engineering Quantum Matter” at St. Andrews University.  The lecture by Seamus Davis from Cornell University focused on “Visualizing Matter” using images from his pioneering work using scanning probe microscopes at low temperatures. ; 3)  A montage from lectures on the “Big Ideas in Quantum Materials” workshop at UCSD in 2015; 4) examples of active matter in action from the workshop on “Soft Active Matter” which sought to find common physical laws describing the collective motion of such seemingly disparate agents as ants and motor proteins.

 

Intellectual Merit.

 

The 31 workshops covered the broad spectrum of emergent phenomena in matter, from understanding how new science discoveries can be applied application oriented projects such as bioimaging and new organic FET, to fundamental issues such as the influence of chirality (twistedness) in nanometer scale phases of matter, and the exploration of how the interaction of electronic magnetic moments (spin) and motion (orbit) can provide new phases of matter in magnetic systems, insulating materials, and at the interfaces between compounds made of transition metal atoms and oxygen.  In every case, the workshops were (i) discussion oriented, with nearly as much time spent to interacting about science as presenting cutting edge lectures from leaders in the field, (ii) supported by this award to bring US senior and junior scientists to these discussions, (iii) we selected workshops best able to provide a sense of organizing principles for the emergent phenomena discussed.

 

The workshops also engendered new collaborations.  Some examples include

  • John Morton (University College London) and Irfan Siddiqi (University of  California, Berkeley) organized a collaboration on using Josephson Parametric Ampli?ers for applications in high-sensitivity electron spin resonance and circuit QED with spins and superconducting resonators at the “Engineering Quantum Matter” workshop.
  • At the workshop “Kinetic Networks from Topology to Design” held in Santa Fe in September 2015, Andy Ferguson from University of Illinois initiated a collaboration with David Wales from Cambridge on using advanced tools in machine learning to improve the understanding and usefulness of Wales’ extensive database on energy landscapes in biomolecules with an eye on studying the kinetics of moving in these landscapes. 
  • A new collaboration on the coldest matter in the universe (ultracold atoms in magnetic traps) may emerge between Bryce Gadway (University of Illinois) and Kaden Hazzard (Rice) which involves engineering models for quantum magnetism by modulating arrays of atoms with stroboscopic light pulsing.   
  • David Hu (Georgia Tech) and Cristina Marchetti (Syracuse) have discussed using active matter models to describe the plastic response of agglomerates of fire ants.

 

Broader Impacts

 

ICAM workshops play a significant role in training the next generation of materials scientists, as we have consistently emphasized support for junior scientists (graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who are between graduate school and permanent jobs).  This emphasis on inclusion of junior scientists (who receive ½-2/3 of the support to our meetings) marks a difference between ICAM and other institutions supporting workshops.  We also demand efforts from our organizers to improve the diversity of participants from underrepresented groups and women in science, and while the majority of our support is centered in the physics community (about 70%), we do work for multidisciplinary outreach, notably in chemistry, biology, and materials science.  In particular, The international aspect of ICAM workshops is a strong feature as the most important problems are being solved by concerted effort within active international communities. We also ask for and often receive positive outreach from our workshops in terms of open lectures to the community and video records of the meeting presentations when they don’t conflict with publication or intellectual property embargoes.

 

Among specific outcomes we are proud of are:

  • The public lecture by the outstanding presenter Seamus Davis at the Engineering Quantum Matter workshop on “Visualizing Quantum Matter”.
  • The first ICAM meeting held at a Historically Black University, Florida A&M, in May 2015 (BioEnabled Self Assembly).
  • Strong participation by women in our workshops including: 35% women at the Engineering Quantum Matter workshop, 33% at the CORSO15 Workshop in Summer of 2015, 29% at the China Summer School on Quantum Matter in 2015, 22% women at the Soft Active Matter workshop, and 22% participation by women overall in the 2014-2015 workshops.
